data.message: Imagine how the Rosetta Mission's descent might look if you were an observer at Comet 67P. Take a ride down to the comet yourself in this new video visualising the final stages of #CometLanding:

Sculpted by ancient water flowing on the surface and one of the most remarkable outflow channels on Mars, Mawrth Vallis was once a potentially habitable place. Seen here by ESA's Mars Express, with a length of 600 km and a depth of up to 2 km, it is one of the biggest valleys on Mars. See http://www.esa.int/spaceinimages/Images/2016/09/Mawrth_Vallis_martian_mosaic

ESA scientists and engineers René Demets, Guan-Lu Zhang, Vinita Marwaha, Jorge Vago and James Carpenter together with Argotec’s Anna Frosi share what inspired them to work in space, and join Europe's voyage of exploration. #space4inspiration

This shining disc of a spiral galaxy is NGC 24, discovered by British-German astronomer William Herschel in 1785, is viewed here by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope. But there's more to this picture than first meets the eye. Astronomers suspect that spiral galaxies like NGC 24 and our Milky Way are surrounded by, and contained within, extended haloes of mysterious 'dark matter'. Most of NGC 24’s mass — a whopping 80% — is thought to be held within such a dark halo... Read more at http://www.spacetelescope.org/images/potw1639a/

A close-up of the Khonsu region on Comet 67P, showing a large boulder, taken with the Rosetta Mission OSIRIS narrow-angle camera on 17 September from 7 km. The scale is 13 cm/pixel and the image measures about 266 m across. See http://www.esa.int/spaceinimages/Images/2016/09/Comet_on_17_September_2016_OSIRIS_narrow-angle_camera

Today, the Rosetta Mission is being tracked by five ground stations: ESA's 35m dishes at Malargüe, Argentina, and New Norcia, Australia, and by NASA's deep space network dishes DSS 14 (70m, Goldstone, USA), 55 (34m, Madrid, Spain) and 43 - this one is the 70m antenna at Canberra, Australia, the largest steerable parabolic antenna in the southern hemisphere! (pic: NASA)

In case you missed it - the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope has found an #exoplanet orbiting not just one, but TWO suns! 

Luke Skywalker, are you watching? #Tatooine
Comet #67P again on 20 September, this time from a distance of 9 km! Resolution 15 cm/pixel. See https://planetgate.mps.mpg.de/Image_of_the_Day/public/OSIRIS_IofD_2016-09-23.html
Our next ESA astronaut to the International Space Station is Thomas Pesquet. Read more about his #Proxima mission here:

Brief but powerful outbursts seen from Comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko during its most active period last year have been traced back to their origins on the surface. In the three months centred around the comet’s closest approach to the Sun, on 13 August 2015, Rosetta’s cameras captured 34 outbursts. Read more here:

A Comet Hitch-hiker's Guide to the Galaxy... um, sorry, Comet Activity... 

How to spot the difference between jets and outbursts in Rosetta Mission #67P pics. #CometLanding #DontPanic See http://ow.ly/90xw304ufYQ

OSIRIS wide-angle camera image taken on 20 September, when the Rosetta Mission was about 13 km from Comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko. The scale is 1.28 m/pixel and the image measures about 2.6 km across. See http://www.esa.int/spaceinimages/Images/2016/09/Comet_on_20_September_2016_OSIRIS_wide-angle_camera

Rosetta Mission NavCam image taken on 18 September when the spacecraft was about 10 km from Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko. The scale at the surface is about 1.0 m/pixel and the image measures about 1.1 km across. See http://www.esa.int/spaceinimages/Images/2016/09/Comet_on_18_September_2016_NavCam
WATCH: a test-firing of Ariane 5’s powerful solid rocket booster - the largest produced in Europe generating 700 tonnes of thrust for liftoff!
We're at the 67th 67th International Astronautical Congress (IAC) in #Guadalajara, Mexico, next week, talking about the Rosetta Mission, #Ariane6 and much more! #IAC2016
Today: 50th anniversary of the nauguration of Europe's sounding rocket range at Kiruna, Sweden.
Highlights of Day 1 of New Scientist Live!

In just a few days' time, ESA's Rosetta mission is going to come to a close in a most extraordinary fashion, because the spacecraft is going to slowly, and deliberately crash-land into the comet that it has been orbiting for the past two years... euronews is with the Rosetta Mission team.

From Hipparchus to Hipparcos: Sonifications of stellar catalogues throughout history, demonstrating the remarkable progress that has been made in the lead up to the first data release from ESA's Gaia mission. Now live via ESA's SoundCloud channel. Some stellar sounds!!!! More at http://sci.esa.int/gaia/58311-from-hipparchus-to-hipparcos-a-sonification-of-stellar-catalogues/

Large chunks of broken ice float in east-central Kazakhstan’s Alakol Lake in this Copernicus Sentinel-2 image from 5 April 2016. This salt lake’s mineral-rich water and mud is considered to be therapeutic, and tourists often visit the lake’s northern shores to remedy skin ailments. Alakol means ‘multicoloured lake’ – and we can see varying shades of green and blue depending on the depth, sediments and phytoplankton. 
Image download: http://www.esa.int/spaceinimages/Images/2016/09/Alakol_Lake
Watch on 'Earth from Space':  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yymDxSEDhMg

We're proud to announce that today Vangelis's brand new album, Rosetta, is released - inspired by ESA's Rosetta Mission. 

Official Store: http://po.st/RosettaFBeC
